subtopics.summary: Defines a **Heat Engine** as a device that operates in a cycle, receives heat ($$Q_H$$) from a high-temperature reservoir ($$T_H$$), converts a portion into net work output ($$W_{\\text{net,out}}$$), and rejects the remaining heat ($$Q_L$$) to a low-temperature sink ($$T_L$$).
Defines **Thermal Efficiency** ($$\eta_{\\text{th}}$$) as the performance measure for a heat engine: $$\eta_{\\text{th}} = \\frac{W_{\\text{net,out}}}{Q_H} = 1 - \\frac{Q_L}{Q_H}$$.

subtopics.topic: Components of a Steam Power Plant Cycle
subtopics.summary: Overview of a typical real-world heat engine (steam power plant) and its four main components: **boiler** ($$Q_H$$ in), **turbine** ($$W_{\\text{out}}$$), **condenser** ($$Q_L$$ out), and **pump** ($$W_{\\text{in}}$$).

Introduces **Reversed Cycles** (**Refrigerators** and **Heat Pumps**), which transfer heat from a low-temperature to a high-temperature reservoir and require a net work input ($$W_{\\text{net,in}}$$).

Defines the performance measure for reversed cycles, the **Coefficient of Performance (COP)**: $$COP_{R} = \\frac{Q_L}{W_{\\text{net,in}}}$$ (for cooling) and $$COP_{HP} = \\frac{Q_H}{W_{\\text{net,in}}}$$ (for heating).

Reaffirms the **Kelvin-Planck Statement**—the impossibility of a Perpetual Motion Machine of the Second Kind (PMM2)—by noting that in a cycle, some heat ($$Q_L$$) must always be rejected, meaning $$W_{\\text{net,out}} < Q_H$$.

Introduces the **Carnot Cycle** as the most efficient *reversible* cycle. The **Carnot Principles** state that all reversible heat engines operating between the same two thermal reservoirs have the same efficiency.

Establishes the relationship for a reversible cycle between heat transfer and the absolute temperature scale: $$\frac{Q_H}{Q_L} = \\frac{T_H}{T_L}$$. This leads to the **Maximum Possible Efficiency (Carnot Efficiency)**: $$\eta_{\\text{th,rev}} = 1 - \\frac{T_L}{T_H}$$.
Derives the maximum possible COP for reversible cycles based on absolute temperatures: $$COP_{R, \\text{rev}} = \\frac{T_L}{T_H - T_L}$$ and $$COP_{HP, \\text{rev}} = \\frac{T_H}{T_H - T_L}$$.
Provides visual examples (balloons, food dye diffusion, thermochromic crystals) to illustrate the natural tendency of systems toward equilibrium and the direction of **spontaneous processes**.
